YOU SURVIVED ANOTHER DAY
AND THAT'S NOT NOTHING
You are enough
— Mom, 1993 (laminated)
flip it over
there it is
My name is Agnes Abernathy. I am 54 years old. I live in Dayton, Ohio. After my divorce, the only thing that survived the water damage in my apartment was a laminated recipe card my mother gave me in 1993. It still said "You are enough" on the back in her handwriting. I sat on the kitchen floor for forty minutes. Then I bought a laminator. Then I bought eleven more.
Everything goes away. So I laminate things.

Why Are the Cards Already Scratched?
Because nobody trusts something pristine. A perfect affirmation card is a liar. Our Authenticity Guarantee means every card ships pre-loved: micro-scratches, bent corners, a slight warping from being left on a dashboard in July. These are not defects. They are proof someone carried it.
Who Is Bertram?
Bertram Fuchs was my co-founder and handled the technology. In April 2023 he relocated to Belize with our operating budget, our customer database, and my label printer. We do not discuss Bertram. We have moved on. (We have not moved on.)
What Happened with the Glitter?
In November 2023 the USPS revoked my mailing permit following what they described as "an incident involving excessive glitter contamination of mail processing equipment." I maintain that 3 ounces of biodegradable glitter per envelope is reasonable. We now ship via FedEx.
What Is BlessYourMess.cards?
A competing affirmation card service run by Brenda Sue Keller of Kettering, Ohio. Their cards are NOT laminated. They use STICKERS. Stickers peel. Stickers lie. I have nothing further to say about Brenda Sue.
She knows what she did.
Do You Ship Internationally?
Not since the incident.
Affirmations in the Age of Ephemerality: Why Lamination Matters
By Agnes Abernathy — Originally attributed to Chad, who turned out to also be Bertram
November 14, 2022

There is a particular cruelty to things that dissolve. Receipts fade. Photographs yellow. The note your daughter wrote on the fridge in second grade ‚Äî the one that said "Mom you are a beautiful dinosaur" ‚Äî will eventually curl at the edges and fall behind the appliance where it will live with dust and a 2014 coupon for Arby's. This is the condition we accept. Impermanence as a tax on caring.

But what if you refused? Not in a dramatic way. Not in a way that requires freezing your body or uploading your brain to a server farm in Nevada. What if you just took the thing ‚Äî the small, stupid, beautiful thing someone said to make you feel less alone ‚Äî and you sealed it in plastic? What if you scratched it up first so it looked like it had already been through something, like you, and then you mailed it to a stranger in a hand-addressed envelope? Would that matter? I don't know. But the cards are waterproof, and that's more than I can say for most things.
